story: As restrictions eased across England yesterday, a handful of venues reopened their doors so I went along to find out what you can expectyou choose to visit the silver screen in our new Covid- world.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesOf the major chains, Showcase opened nine venues, Odeon ten with Vue and Cineworld postponing their reopening until later this month.I’m lucky enough to live near Showcase Cinema de Lux at Bluewater shopping centre, in Kent. I’ve missed the chance of watching a film in peace - so a day before the big reopening, I booked tickets online.There was limited choice - and nothing new.For now, it’s mainly nostalgic offerings such as Inception and a k restoration of The Empire Strikes Back. Around  films have been available to England’s cinema operators including The Wizard of Oz, Harry Potter and war drama .I scroll through my options which include Back to the Future and Beauty and the Beat and choose Bohemian Rhapsody, a  biological drama about Freddie Mercury which I hadn’t yet got round to seeing.I book and pay for my tickets online - tickets only cost a fiver - and I am encouraged to pre-order and pay for a drink which will be ready when I arrive.When I arrive, there are one way systems in place to follow and there are still manned tills for those who just turn up, though screens have been erected to protect customer’s and staff. Hand-washing stations and antibacterial wipes are everywhere. At no point, am I asked to wear a mask. Public Health England have not made in mandatory given cinemas don’t sit face to face. Signs ‘encourage’ you to wear one, but it’s not enforced. Neither is my temperature checked.I stand in line to collect my drink and then look around to see what food options are in place. You can still buy ice cream, hotdogs, nachos and popcorn - but sadly, there’s no pick ‘n’ mix, it’s self-service nature would clearly put us at risk of cross-contamination. Everything is sold from behind a screen.I’m directed to scan the ticket from my phone myself and am directed up an escalator to screen . It’s the first time cinemas have been opened in months, and it’s only .am, but it’s already bustling with people. Groups of teens and families going to see Paw Patrol.Toilets are open but at reduced capacity. Every other sink and cubicle are sealed off to make sure customers keep their distance. At busy times, you’d probably need to queue.I head into my film and sit in my pre-booked seat. You don’t have to sit by yourselfyou’re attending with members of your household, but must be at least two-metres apart from everyone . I’ve chosen a quiet showing - there are only three others in the auditorium.It’s actually quite nice having fewer people at the screening. There’s no munch crunch of others eating popcorn behind you and for the first time in months, I sit down and enjoy a film in peace.Did I put myself at risk by going  It’s hard to say and the public seem unsure about how safe it is to go right now, though some are clearly willing to take the risk. I think she is likely to be feeling extremely low and probably struggling.The legal battle and the increased tension it’s created with the royals due to the information that’s coming out has to be putting a lot of strain on them both.“Meghan’s been a lot more distant and introverted over the last few weeks – her family is worried. And Harry must be tormented by his fractured family ties.He was particularly down on William’s birthday on June .”It also emerged in the court papers Meghan had named five friends who gave an interview to US People magazine defending her and criticising her father.But she denies authorising them to do it.Meghan has also claimed she was the subject of a number of damaging and distressing articles, with Kensington Palace ordering her to say nothing but “no comment”.Her legal document stated: “As her friends had never seen her in this state before, they were rightly concerned for her welfare, specically as she was pregnant, unprotected by the Institution, and prohibited from defending herself.”The Mail on Sunday published extracts from a letter Meghan had written to her father in August .It was written three months after he was unable to walk her down the aisle following a heart attack.Meghan has claimed the letter was private.The newspaper has denied the allegations, saying Mr Markle wanted its content published to correct any  impression her friends had given about what it contained when they gave their magazine interviews.Meghan has identied one of her five pals, Friend A, as the person who told People magazine the letter said: “Dad, I’m so heartbroken. I love you. I have one father.“Please stop victimising me through the media so we can repair our relationship.”Meghan claimed this was an “unfortunately inaccurate” portrayal of her letter, claiming she didn’t know her friend would go public.The Duchess recently “cut ties” with her friend Jessica Mulroney after she became caught up in a race row.The pair had been friends for years, ever since they met in Canada when Mulroney, , introduced the then TV star to Toronto’s social set.Mulroney and her three kids played a prominent role in Meghan’s royal wedding at Windsor Castle in  when she married Prince Harry.She became embroiled in a war of words with lestyle blogger Sasha Exeter, who claimed Mulroney had taken offence to her generic call to action asking white influencers to speak out amid the Black Lives Matter protests.Mulroney was forced to publicly apologise after Exeter accused her of exhibiting textbook white privilege behaviour. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what today pollen count uk level london
story: But just how bad is it for people with hay fever  Here is todays pollen count, and also how sufferers can protect themselves.Heres the pollen forecast for dferent regions of the UK as of Saturday, July , .Across the whole of England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland pollen counts have remained at moderate levels all day.Pollen levels are expected to rise in England through Sunday.Scotland and Northern Ireland meanwhile will have low pollen levels, apart from Aberdeen which will have a moderate amount.To try and combat the effects of hay fever, you can try a number of things:In times of high pollen, do not cut grass or walk in grassy areas, do not keep fresh flowers in your home, smoke or dry clothes outside as they can catch pollen.There are two ways which might be useful for hay fever sufferers to track periods of high pollen.The Met Office issues a five day pollen forecast which monitors the pollen count across the UK which you can find here.Tech-savvy hay fever sufferers can also download the Hay Fever Relief app which can alert you to the daily pollen count updates as well as give you an expert treatment plan and allow you to track your symptoms.A pollen count is generated by measuring the number of pollen grains in a given volume of air, using a pollen trap.A count of  pollen grains or less is considered low, and a count of , pollen grains or more is considered high.Pollen counts tend to be higher in early morning and late evening, although they can sometimes be high all day long.If the grass is damp, the pollen peak will be later in the morning because the water evaporates before the pollen is released.Pollen rises in the air during the day and then descends at night, as the air cools.In rural areas, the evening peak tends to occur between pm and pm but in the city, where the air stays warmer for longer, the pollen descends later and levels tend to peak between pm and midnight or even later, which is why you may wake up sneezing in the night.Sunny days favour higher pollen counts and rain tends to wash the pollen away, whereas on a cloudy day, pollen builds up only to be released on the next sunny day.

title: pubs uk super saturday coronavirus lockdown pints
story: Thousands of Brits poured into pubs and restaurants that reopened yesterday for the first time in  days. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBrits sunk  million pints yesterday as lockdown restrictions were eased. Pubs nationwide now look a lot dferent to before they closed in March — with one-way systems, masked staff, screens, and customers ordering drinks via apps.But the changes — and some price hikes — did not dampen peoples enthusiasm.Rowdy boozers were seen emerging from busy pubs in London, Blackpool and Newcastle.However pubs in four Nottinghamshire towns were closed early due to bad behaviour, and four people were arrested.Inspector Craig Berry from Nottinghamshire Police said: Officers were quickly on the scene to deal with a number of alcohol related anti-social behaviour reports including a smashed window and minor assault.As a result four arrests were made by officers and we supported licensees who chose to close their own premises.A pub in Narborough, Leicestershire, also had to shut early after a punter was assaulted and suffered neck injuries.Meanwhile a vicious brawl broke out on the High Street in Brentwood, Essex, where another four people were arrested.Special Inspector Steve Weaver tweeted: That didnt last long. Disturbance in Brentwood High street assisted other units.  people arrested.  of my team have arrested and are currently on the way to custody.Devon and Cornwall Police received more than , reports, most of which were drink-related.John Apter, Chair of the Police Federation, said he dealt with naked men, happy drunks, angry drunks, fights and more angry drunks on sht in Southampton.He said: What was crystal clear is that drunk people cant wont socially distance.It was a busy night but the sht managed to cope. I know other areas have had issues with officers being assaulted.It came after Boris Johnson warned punters dont let us down as he urged them to stick to social distancing.Excited Brits hit pubs across England for Super Saturday as locals reopened after a four-month lockdown.Drinkers were sinking pints all day as pubs threw open their doors from am - with the revellers largely sticking to the rules and keeping safe.Some spots, like Borough Market in London, were packed with punters in large groups getting stuck into Super Saturday.One eager Brit downed a Jagerbomb live on BBC News as he celebrated pubs reopening.The cheeky punter told the amused presenter cheers as he raised his glass and then sank it in one at am.Punters had queued outside pubs ahead of the early morning start before tucking into breakfast bevvies.Fire protection installers Ben Clark, , Curtis Birch, , and Connor Cowen, , were first in line after finishing a night sht in Birmingham city centre.Ben said he’d been craving a pint since the start of lockdown, adding: “We walked past and saw the lights on and got ourselves booked in.”Andrew Slawinski, , had a Guinness at am — and said his first pub pint in more than three months was gorgeous. Supping it at the Toll Gate in Turnpike Lane, North London, he added: Its like winning the League.The Prime Minister urged Brits to be sensible and stick to the rules, despite the restrictions being relaxed - and he threatened more local lockdownsBrits dont behave.But Health Secretary Matt Hancock said today: Overall I’m pleased with what happened yesterday, it was really good to see people out and about and largely social distancing.Pubs shut their doors when they were ordered to temporarily close amid the pandemic, but the Government gave the green light to start serving again yesterday.Restaurants and cafes are also allowed to start serving customers again and not just for takeaways.Weve also reported on a new map showing you which beer gardens will be open this weekend.Pubs have been kitted out with screens, posters and floor markings to help keep customers safe.But Greene King pubs are not due toand welcome customers until Monday - to give landlords and managers enough time to make sure branches are Pubsafe - or Covid- secure.PUBS: Screens up to protect staff and tables a metre apart, with one-way systems. Table service or app ordering in place. Up to six people can sit outside butindoors you cant mix with another household. Live music is banned and shouting is not encouraged. Booking tables in advanced is required in many spots.EATING OUT: Cafes and restaurants are now open, but must keep distancing in place. Again no more than six to a table, and screens and one-way systems should be in place. Most places will only take bookings and only table service is allowed. Most venues will only allow contactless or app payments.CINEMAS: Showcase is the only chain reopening all cinemas today. There will be allocated seats, online booking and staggered film times and cinema-goers must download tickets.WEDDINGS: Marriages and civil partnerships are allowed only  people, including the couple, witnesses and officiants. Small socially-distanced celebrations should take the place of receptions. Only two households can be close indoors and up to six people outdoors.DAYS OUT: Theme parks, adventure parks and funfairs can open along with zoos and safari parks. But water parks and water rides have to stay closed. Tickets should be bought online and a face covering is needed.People living near the English border in Wales had to watch on as pubs open just miles away - with their locals still locked down until July .Those within five miles of an English open pub could visit under the restrictions in Wales, but the First Minister Mark Drakeford begged people to stay safe.Statistics from the Night-Time Industries Associationrevealed  per cent of bars, pubs and restaurants stayed closed on Saturday.Chief executive Michael Kill called for more support for the industry from the Government and said: Our members feel stuck in a bizarre tug of war between government, licensing and planning regulators and the police.But no-one knows which rope to pull and in which direction, leaving businesses stranded in the middle with no way to move forward and out of this mess.But going back the local wont be the same as it was before - youll have to stick to tough new rules to keep everyone safe during the coronavirus pandemic.Mr Johnson bluntly told people not to blow it, as distancing is still in place, groups of more than six still cannot mingle and masks should be worn in enclosed areas where possible.People will only be allowed to go out to the pub with one other household at a time.And the lead member will have to leave their contact details with the pub just in case theres an outbreak, or they end up near someone who later tests positive for the virus.Those details will be destroyed by the pubs after  days.The Sun revealed this week pubs will be allowed to show the football.Anything which encourages people to raise their voice shouldnt be allowed - because of the potential to spread the virus through droplets in the air.And people in Scotland will have to wait a little longer before they can enjoy a cold pint at their pub - as beer gardens arent meant to open until  July.Indoor restaurants and pubs can open their doors from  July, too.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Since March, millions of clinically vulnerable people have been shut indoors practically the whole time, until recently not even leaving for exercise. Now a plan to unlock those doors - in two stages on July  and August  - has been revealed by the government. From July  shielding people can go out and meet up to five friends in a socially distanced way. And cruciallythey live alone, they can also form a aposbubbleapos with another household - allowing millions to hug and kiss their closest family or friends for the first time. Then, from August , the advice to shield ends completely. The exception is in Leicester, where current rules on shielding will remain due to a local lockdown. The ability to go outside and hug and kiss will be welcome relief for millions whose mental health has taken a toll. But charities warn there is too much dangerous ambiguity and people could have vital support withdrawn. Sick pay and a system of food deliveries will end on July  - which they fear could leave shielded people in the lurch. So what are the changes and what are the implications for you and the ones you love   From Monday  July, there are two major changes for all .million people who are shielding in England. Firstly, people who are shielding are able to join gatherings of up to six people outdoors. These gatherings can be from up to six dferent households - but anyone from separate households must maintain a -metre distance. This follows the rules that were unveiled for the rest of England from June .  Secondly, people who are shielding and live alonewill be able to join the apossupport bubbleapos system topair up permanently with one other household. They will be able to break the two-metre rule with people inside their bubble to hug and kiss. One of the two households - the shielded household - must be a single-adult household. The other household can have an unlimited number of people. What will change from August   From Saturday  August, the .million clinically vulnerable people in England will officially be told they no longer have to shield from the virus. It will bring to an end a period of isolation lasting more than four months. While they should strictly follow social distancing rules, they will be able to go back to workthey cannot work from home, and visit shops and places of worship. Will shielding support end on August   Not completely - but a lot of it will. The governmentaposs direct food parcel and medicine deliveries will end. Matt Hancock confirmed they “continue to the end of July”. And shielding people will no longer be paid Statutory Sick Pay - unless they develop symptoms or are told to isolate. That brings them in line with the rest of the population. The government claims help wonapost simply end at the stroke of midnight on July . NHS Volunteer Responders will still be able to help with collecting shopping or medication, a regular friendly phone call, or transport to appointments. Shielding people will also retain their priority for supermarket delivery slots. But Nick Moberly, Chief Executive of the MS Society, warned: “We are gravely concerned that certain key support measures – such as food packages and Statutory Sick Pay – will be taken away prematurely. Without this help, and with many people still terried of infection, for some the idea of normal le ing will feel more like a threat than an opportunity. WhatIaposm scared toto work on August   Itaposs up to you and your employer - not the government. This is likely to prompt a major row from campaigners who want guaranteed legal protection for workers. The government press release says: From  August, those who need to work and cannot do so from home will be able toto work as long as their workplace is COVID secure, adhering to the  guidance available. But it does not say what will happenpeople feel too frightened or clinically vulnerable to go back. And government sources confirmed this would be a conversation between a worker and their employer - rather than a set legal protection. Health Secretary Matt Hancock told employers: We expect you to do the right thing. Nick Moberly, Chief Executive of the MS Society, warned: “Those who now may have no choice but toto work must be given the right information so that – together with their employer – they can ensure their working environment is safe. We also need clarity on what ‘carefully following social distancing’ means in the real world, in situations like shopping or meeting friends. But households are only meant to pick one bubble buddy and stick with that one, not switch around. Could I end up having to shield all over again  Yes,there is a second wave of the pandemic. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the shielding list will be maintained and “we stand ready to support people to shield againthat is what’s clinically required”. story: NewsopinionKeir Starmer: The best way to celebrate NHS nd birthday is by giving staff pay riseA happy birthday to our NHS, and a thank you to all those who have served in it - but the best praise for our healthcare heroes and their helpers would come in their wage packetsShareCommentsByKeir Starmer:,  JUL NewsopinionSir Keir Starmer shares his good wishes and hopes for the NHS as it turns  ", url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe NHS is personal to all of us. Today, on its nd birthday, we have the chance not just to celebrate it but to reflect on what it means to us. My mum was a nurse, but she was also very ill for much of her le. The NHS she served and loved was also her leline. When I remember the dedication and professionalism of the doctors and nurses who cared for her, I feel a deep sense of gratitude. It is what inspires me to fight for our health system, to ensure that kind of care will always be available to everyone. I know many others feel the same. The NHS means so much to so many. But in the last few months, as we have battled the coronavirus, it has become even more important. The impact of Covid- across our country has been devastating. Friends and families have been kept apart and tens of thousands of lives have been taken too early, including hundreds of NHS workers. At the centre of this storm, our NHS has been a rock. For every le tragically lost, many more have been saved by the actions of our NHS heroes.  I know it has been incredibly hard for those on the front line. Day in, day out, they put themselves in harm’s way to save others. We must never forget who our key workers are. For them, it’s more than a job. Their deep sense of public service and desire to help people in need shine through. They are the best of us. That’s why Labour supports those calling on the Government to make an immediate commitment to talks on a pay rise for NHS workers, and to agree this deal as soon as possible. The numbers of deaths are, at last, coming down. But Covid- has not gone away. The threat from the virus is still very real.  Throughout this crisis, the Government has been too slow. Too slow into lockdown, too slow to ramp up testing, too slow to fix the test-and-trace system and much too slow to get PPE to the front line of the NHS. The situation we saw in Leicester this week shows that the Government has still not got a grip on quickly identying and containing local outbreaks. We need to remain vigilant and do everything we can to protect and support our NHS.  That’s why Labour is calling on ministers to publish an NHS winter resilience plan, with free flu jabs for over-s, weekly coronavirus testing for NHS and social care staff, and proper stockpiling of PPE. The Government must learn from the mistakes made in their response to the virus so far and help the NHS prepare for winter. That includes facing up to the scandal that allowed the virus to ravage our care homes. We need to eliminate the virus from care homes before winter sets in.

story: NewsDoctors told me I had IBS, an hour later I gave birth to baby girl in the toiletEXCLUSIVE: Fitness-mad mum Charlotte Wheeler-Smith, , welcomed perfect baby girl in just three pushes after doing a km run, km walk and cycling sessionShareCommentsByKelly Jenkins:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsCharlotte Wheeler-Smith, Dominic and their baby Evelyn Rose - whose arrival was a complete surprise ", url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailStrange cramps had ­Charlotte Wheeler-Smith wondering what was going on inside her tummy... and nothing could have quite ­prepared her for the answer. Lawyer Charlotte, , had done a km run, a km walk and a session with a personal trainer when the niggling pain kicked in.Incredibly, her doctor made a house call to examine Charlotte, and he said it was most likely trapped wind or irritable bowel syndrome.But just an hour later Charlotte suddenly went into labour. She was about to give birth – yet didn’t even know she was pregnant. A wave of panic and mixed emotions swept over her but Charlotte still stayed cool. She phoned boyfriend Dominic – who was out on a run – then an ambulance. Dominic got back in time for Charlotte to give birth in just three pushes. But little Evelyn Rose was born breach and Charlotte suffered an umbilical cord prolapse, meaning her baby was starved of oxygen. Charlotte says: “I had absolutely no idea I was pregnant. The only signs were stomach cramps two days before she was born. “I thought I’d eaten something bad, or it was period pains, but I called a doctor on the morning before she was born, to be sure. “He visited and said I had trapped gas and IBS. Then an hour later, I went to the toilet and an umbilical cord fell out of me. I could not believe what was happening. “I got a sudden urge to push, then two little feet popped out. I was astonished, but I knew from watching One Born Every Minute that an umbilical cord coming out first is not good, because the baby is being starved of oxygen. “And a breach delivery is harder. So I knew that I had to push with everything I had. “I was strangely calm. I just knew I had to get our baby out.” Evelyn Rose was born in a corridor at Dominic’s flat in Amsterdam, where he and fellow Londoner Charlotte live. Dominic, , picks up the story: “We’d called an ambulance, but I saw the little legs and, at this point, it’s just me and Charlotte.  “I rang the emergency services back and said, ‘You’ve got to get here now, guys!’ Charlotte is standing there, holding on to the legs. She pushed once, and it was half way up the baby’s calves, she pushed again and it was up to the hips. “With the final push, the baby dropped out. Just three pushes. Charlotte grabbed her and passed her to me. She was really floppy and blue. Then we started chest compressions and tried to get air into her. “In the meantime, the ambulance crew turned up and started working on her.” Charlotte continues: “I shouted, ‘Oh my gosh, it’s a little girl.’ I’ve always wanted a little girl – a mini- me. I looked at her and she was so beautul, with dark curly hair. I shouted, ‘Is she alive ’ I really thought at that moment she was dead. Dominic had given her CPR that he remembered being taught in primary school. She was whisked away in an ambulance and we were taken in another. “I didn’t knowshe was alive or dead. Then the emotional rollercoaster started. As a woman who has just had a baby, your emotions are all over the place – I desperately wanted her to survive.” The couple – reeling from the shock of having a baby at all – faced an anxious wait to find outEvelyn was brain damaged. Charlotte adds: “Five days later, the neurosurgeon came back and said to the doctor, ‘Have you sent me the correct scan, because this baby’s brain is absolutely fine.’ She has no brain damage at all – a real miracle given the way she was born. We were so relieved, I burst into tears. We are so, so lucky to have her. She’s a dream come true. “Being able to hold her for the first time four days after her birth was the best feeling in the world. It felt amazing and so special.” Two-week-old Evelyn is recovering well and has been moved out of ICU and on to the children’s ward. To say Charlotte was stunned to become a mum is an understatement.  She had no baby bump and had been having regular periods. Evelyn’s arrival came after a worrying time for Charlotte, who was overweight in her s and feared that might prevent her having children. “I was  stone and my periods were very irregular, so I knew falling pregnant would be a struggle,” she says. In , after a diplomatic word from a friend, Charlotte joined Slimming World, started working out and lost a whopping st in  months – dropping from a size  to size -. She now writes a blog about her weight loss journey, called Slimming and the City, and shares exercise and recipe tips. In , she met Dominic on Tinder and embarked on a long-distance romance with the telecommunications company director, who has lived in Amsterdam for  years.  While they had discussed marriage and children, neither was prepared for the shock birth of baby Evelyn. Charlotte adds: “Because of lockdown, we’d been apart for  weeks, so when I got to Amsterdam three weeks ago, we had a lovely reunion. “Who could have guessed just a few weeks later we would be parents ” Luckily, Charlotte is not a big drinker and hadn’t been consuming much alcohol during her pregnancy. She exercised vigorously daily – running, indoor cycling, exercise classes – and travelled quite a bit too. She goes on: “I feel really guilty I didn’t realise I was pregnant, when I think of the things I have done while she was in my tummy.  “Crazy exercise, personal training sessions. All the travel. “I went to Dubai in February and ended up playing Uno and drinking Hennessey Paradis – which is £, a bottle – with Tottenham footballer Dele Alli on the flight. Luckily that was the only time I really drank. Drinking for me is a single glass of Prosecco on a Friday night. “I also had surgery when I was two months pregnant – a breast uplt and skin removal after losing so much weight. They did a pregnancy test, but it came back negative! “Two days before I gave birth, I started with a run, followed by a walk and an online training session. “Then I worked and cycled into Amsterdam to go to the pub. Two days later, Evelyn Rose was born. Our little miracle. I’m so, so proud of my body and all it has achieved.”

story: NewsDogs incredible transformation from looking like bag of bones with rotting fleshWhen Nicola Owst stumbled upon a neglected dog trapped in a crate in a field, little did she know he would become a rescue project that would turn her le aroundShareCommentsByLouise Burke:,  JUL NewsPoor Buddy was in a terrible state when Nicola found him ", url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs part of aposA Dog is for Le not Just for Lockdown, Notebook magazineaposs campaign with the Dogaposs Trust, Nicola tells the harrowing story of how she saved the le of her beautul dog Buddy. It was  April  when my friend Sally and I decided to take a trip to view a foal she’d seen for sale on the internet. Sally ran a stables with her husband Rob in Leicestershire, where I’d spent much of my teenage years living and working with horses. It was a bit of a mission to drive down the M in the pouring rain. We had to then weave through tiny B roads and muddy lanes to see this foal, but Sally was the type of person who would go above and beyond to give an animal a loving new home. When we arrived at the address, we both had a funny feeling in the pit of our stomachs. It was clear it was not a proper paddock – it was the grimmest, scariest place I’d ever been to. Two shady-looking men came out and showed us the six-month foal. I was horried to see it looked half-starved and riddled with worms. There wasn’t just one, but two of them. We quickly handed over the cash and coaxed the nervous foals into our trailer. Just as we were about to leave, I spotted an animal wedged into the back of a rusty metal crate. I crept closer to see whether it was even alive. The poor creature, squashed inside a cat carrier, was breathing faintly. His sad eyes were just slits in his bony, bruised face. It looked astrying to keep them open was causing him intense pain. I couldn’t believe what I was seeing. His fur had worn away, showing his paper-thin skin over his bony rib-cage and face. His mottled flesh looked like it had been clawed at. He was barely alive. This poor dog had been trapped in his own waste and had obviously had no food or water for days. But what really hit me was the horrendous smell – a combination of rotting flesh and faeces. His little paw pads were burnt and red raw from standing in his own urine. It was unbelievably sad. I didn’t think twice about rescuing him. I swaddled him in a towel and took him back to our x. His legs buckled from underneath him as I carefully placed him on my knee. On closer inspection, I could see he was covered in mange – a nasty infection caused by mites that burrow under the skin. I had to save this poor creature from these horrible people. ‘I’ve got you, Buddy,’ I said to him. The name stuck. We made a sharp exit from that hellhole.  I knew exactly who to call on when we got home – Ian, the local vet, who had tended to the horses at the stables for years. He examined him straight away. Sitting on the examining table in the veterinary practice, Buddy resembled a bag of bones. Ian confirmed he was a Staffordshire bull terrier, probably not even a year old. I watched over Buddy as Ian checked him out. You’d think he would be frightened of me and the environment, but I think he was relieved. The way he looked at me made me think he was grateful to be saved. The vet diagnosed him with demodectic mange. Because he’d been left in his own mess, he’d got secondary infections and his skin was rotting away. Armed with a bag of antibiotics and care instructions from Ian, I took Buddy home. That first night I bathed him gently in the kitchen sink, then I didn’t sleep a wink, constantly checkinghe was breathing. It felt touch and go at times… We took everything slowly. I introduced small plates of chicken or scrambled egg to him so as not to upset his stomach, and gave him just enough exercise in between lots of sleep. If I’m honest, the Staffy breed hadn’t always appealed to me. I had it in my head they were aggressive dogs. But I couldn’t have been more wrong. He is the most loving, kind and loyal dog I’ve ever come across.  Over the following year, Buddy grew stronger and his infections cleared up. I made a point of socialising him even in puppyhood. He was my number one in le, and he soon won the hearts of those close to me. At the stables, Sally’s mum, Phyllis, who we called Gran, had a special bond with him. Instead of running around in the fields, playing with other dogs, he’d prefer to curl up on the sofa with Gran. When she was diagnosed with diabetes, he wouldn’t leave her side until she had her insulin. He’s very intuitive. When it came to finding myself a partner, it was a case of ‘love me, love Buddy and my horses too’. I was lucky to meet Jon through work, and he took us on as a package. To find a man who was happy to love us all meant the world. Of course, we had Buddy as a guest of honour at our wedding in . He had a special outfit for the pictures – my great auntie who has since passed away, made him a fancy collar to match my bridesmaids. Our le as a family of three was going smoothly until Buddy was diagnosed with cancer in March .  It happened the same year I went through two miscarriages. It was a very traumatic time. In a way, him being ill shted the focus away from me. I channelled any emotional energy I had on him getting better. And after numerous rounds of radiotherapy and chemotherapy, he made a recovery in October . The following autumn, I fell pregnant with my son Toby, who is now three.Before Toby arrived, we got another dog, a springer spaniel called Susie, who was rescued from a puppy farm where she was a breeding bitch for three years in a shed. I still haven’t quite worked my magic on her, she can be nervous, whereas I can take Buddy anywhere, and do anything. He’s so well-behaved. I feel like I have a lot to thank Buddy for. I’ve experienced so many things in my le because of him – we’ve been to dog shows like Crufts and won awards, met celebrities like Martin Clunes and Christine Lampard, and have a fantastic circle of friends we’ve met through Buddy, who we holiday with twice a year. Who would have thought that poor, neglected dog I first saw in the cage could have turned my le around for the better

title: boy who touched comedy stars
story: NewsBoy who touched comedy stars hearts now in Mexico for last chance to save his leCharlie, , has battled medulloblastoma since he was eight and won support from John Bishop, fellow comedian Katherine Ryan and actor Chris O’Dowd at a Stand Up To Cancer eventShareCommentsByAmy Sharpe:,  JUL NewsCharlie out after his latest round of treatment in Mexico ", url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA boy who touched the heart of TV stars is in Mexico for last-chance therapy that might save him. Mum Toni Ilsley raised £, to take son Charlie abroad – though doing so in the Covid- pandemic petried her. Charlie, , has battled medulloblastoma – the highest-grade brain tumour for children – since he was eight. In January he was given months to live. Parents Toni and Mark, , are clinging to the hope that a three-week trial at the Williams’ Cancer Institute in Mexico City can offer a miracle cure. He is midway through treatment led by Dr Jason Williams. It uses a protein in the body to attack tumorous cells. Pharmacist technician Toni, , said from Mexico: “No one at such a young age should be going through what he’s had to endure. Learning the NHS could do no more almost destroyed us. “We were getting to the point doctors said he wouldn’t live past – but thankfully we scraped the funds to get to Mexico. I was petried to take Charlie but told myselfI don’t, he will die. It’s his last chance. So far, so good, though it’s too early to say. Charlie is in good spirits and swimming between therapy.”  The family has won support from John Bishop, fellow comedian Katherine Ryan and actor Chris O’Dowd. They met at a Stand Up To Cancer event which helped raise £, to send Charlie to Turkey for CyberKne radiotherapy treatment. That was in  – after Charlie’s brain tumours spread. The treatment worked, he was declared cancer-free but the cruel disease ed last November.  Mum-of-three Toni, from Henley, Oxfordshire, says she was told no more could be done. She said: “I went into shock, I couldn’t eat or sleep. We tried to make it the best Christmas, knowing it could be his last.” With the NHS offering palliative chemo, the family went private – paying £, so Charlie could get drugs through a reservoir inserted under his scalp. But after one of four treatments, appointments were halted due to Covid-.  Toni said: “Every door was closing. I researched America and Turkey, but the pandemic made it hard to find anyone to treat Charlie. Finding Doctor Williams was a miracle. I sent Charlie’s scans and we spoke for hours on Skype. Eventually, he said Charlie was eligible.”  Arriving in Mexico brought its own drama – earthquake tremors hurtling Charlie across a room as he lay in bed. “We thought we would die,” said Toni.  She, Mark and Charlie are in Mexico until scans gauge how successful treatment has been. They continue to fundraise in case he needs further therapy. Toni said: “Between treatment we’ve created memories including visiting a ranch where Charlie rode a horse. All we can hope now is that the therapy works.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe easing of the coronavirus lockdown descended into carnage on Englandaposs streets with brawls, men stripping naked and police having to take care of those too drunk to care for themselves. In the aftermath, John Apter, the chairman of the Police Federation, said drunk people are unable to properly socially distance. It was crystal clear revellers would not adhere to the one metre plus rule as restrictions were eased on so-called Super Saturday, he added. Mr Apter was on sht in Southampton, Hampshire, where he dealt with naked men, happy drunks, angry drunks, fights and more angry drunks. He said: What was crystal clear is that drunk people canapost wonapost socially distance. It was a busy night but the sht managed to cope. I know other areas have had issues with officers being assaulted. Some police forces had signalled they were apprehensive about theof pubs on a Saturday and said they were expecting problems. In some places, their fears came true. In Nottinghamshire, police responded to trouble at pubs across Mansfield, Sutton-in-Ashfield, Arnold and Newark. Windows were smashed and at least one person was assaulted as police dealt with several incidents of anti-social behaviour. Four people were arrested and five pubs decided to shut early in a bid to prevent any further trouble. Police said three pubs in Mansfield and Sutton in Ashfield, plus two in Arnold and Newark , closed.Inspector Craig Berry of Nottinghamshire Police said: Officers were quickly on the scene to deal with a number of alcohol related anti-social behaviour reports including a smashed window and minor assault. As a result four arrests were made by officers and we supported licensees who chose to close their own premises. No pubs have been closed by the police. Weaposd like to thank the majority of the public who have acted responsibly throughout Saturday, especially whilst watching the much-anticipated Derby v Forest match.  Devon and Cornwall Police said they had received more than , reports over the so-called Super Saturday, most of which were drink-related. In Leicestershire, police were granted a dispersal order to send people away from Market Harborough town centre after reports of anti-social behaviour. The order was in place between pm on Saturday ad am on Sunday.  Images from Soho in central London showed packed streets into the early hours of Sunday with revellers ignoring the one-metre plus social distancing rule which was introduced on Saturday. One man who passed through the busy streets told : Walking down old Compton Street felt like wading through a Petri dish. Photos showed carnage in the streets in London, Manchester, Bristol, Leeds and Newcastle. Pubs were allowed to reopen from am for the first time since the lockdown began in late March after Boris Johnsonaposs government decided it would be safe to do so.Many reopened at am or am and there wasnapost an immediate rush, but venues became busy in the afternoon and through the evening, when trouble flared. It was estimated , pubs would reopen and customers would sink  million pints from Saturday. Nik Antona, the national chairman of the Campaign for Real Ale , said feedback from branches suggeted up to half of pubs did not reopen. Many licensees criticised insufficient notice from the government and were taking a wait and see approach, he added.A major easing of lockdown measures in England saw pubs, restaurants, hairdressers, theme parks and cinemas opening their doors again under modied social distancing regulations. The National Police Chiefs Council issued a joint appeal with the hospitality industry calling on drinkers to behave responsibly when pubs reopened. Prime Minister Boris Johnson and government experts had urged people to stick to the rules on Super Saturday to avoid creating a second wave of coronavirus.

title: dad 3 completes 270 marathons
story: NewsDad of  completes  marathons around world despite living with Parkinsons diseaseEXCLUSIVE: Dad of three Alex Flynn was diagnosed with Parkinsons disease at the age of just  but since  hes tackled some of the world’s most physically challenging racesShareCommentsByPunteha van Terheyden:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsAlex cycling as part of the  trans-America challenge ", url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAt the age of just , Alex Flynn was diagnosed with Parkinson’s ­disease – but he refused to let it hold him back. Instead, the former solicitor has gone on to tackle some of the world’s most physically challenging races and has never let his degenerative condition stand in the way. Alex, now , has ­completed the ­notoriously tough Marathon des Sables in the searing heat of the Sahara Desert, pulled a lb sled across the Arctic in temperatures of -C and run  miles through the Amazon. Since , he has successfully ­completed  marathons and challenges. And the dad of three didn’t let up during lockdown either. He spent  hours a day for a whole week climbing ,ft – more than double the height of Mount Everest – using just his stairs to raise money for charity. So far, Alex’s amazing feats of physical endurance have raised more than £, for Parkinson’s UK and more than £, for charities worldwide. He says: “I have learned to accept the bad days, and give my all on the good. I want to raise £million for Parkinson’s UK in the hope of better treatments or even a cure one day.” Fitness fanatic Alex was diagnosed with Parkinson’s in  after he noticed his little finger moving involuntarily. Following a series of tests, he was told he had the incurable disease, which develops when cells that produce ­dopamine in the brain stop working and are lost over time. In the UK, around , people are living with Parkinson’s and a further two people are diagnosed every hour. There is no cure for the le-changing disease, and sufferers are forced to live with the knowledge that they will slowly lose control of their body as the ­illness progresses.  Alex recalls: “When the ­neurologist told me it was Parkinson’s, my le suddenly felt meaningless. “I was devoid of hope and my diagnosis weighed on me from the moment I woke to the moment I fell asleep. “My twitching finger was a constant physical reminder of the battle I couldn’t fight and wouldn’t win.” But after months of ­feeling both anger and ­despair, Alex realised that he couldn’t ­wallow. Instead, he focused on his work as a lawyer and ploughed all his energy into athletic events he’d planned to do ­before his diagnosis.  Alex continued training for the Marathon des Sables – a -mile race across the Sahara Desert, known as the “toughest footrace on the Earth”. During the event, Alex got lost and had to be rescued by local tribesmen. He then became seriously ill and had to pull out of the race due viral pericarditis – an ­infection of the sac surrounding the heart. Alex was ­gutted he had to quit, but still ­managed to raise £, for charity – which made him realise that his global adventures could really help other people. He says: “This led me to the MillionMetres challenge, which ­involves running, hiking, ­cycling, climbing and rowing ,km.” In , Alex ran  miles across the Alps in  hours, ­surviving on just  minutes’ sleep. And the following year, he ran from London to Rome via Brussels and Paris in  days.  In , he became the first person to cross America using four dferent disciplines – cycling, running, climbing and rowing – covering more than , miles in just  days. He also ran  miles across the Dolomite mountains in Italy and  miles of the Colorado Rockies. More recently, in , Alex took part in Fiji’s -mile Lost Island Ultra before completing the London Marathon a fortnight later. He also trained for Primal Quest in Canada – one of the toughest adventure races in the world. Despite suffering broken ribs, a concussion and a bulging disc in his spine, Alex and his team completed the challenge in four days and five hours. Later this year, he hopes to take part in Racing the Planet’s -mile six-stage ultramarathon on Namibia’s Skeleton Coast. Alex is also hoping to secure ­sponsorship to become the first person with Parkinson’s to climb Mount Everest for real – a challenge he hopes to have professionally filmed.  But in the meantime, from July , he’ll be ­running a -mile ultramarathon in  days for Parkinson’s UK in his home town of Wantage, Oxfordshire. Although Alex does his best to stay fit and healthy, the physical symptoms of his condition sometimes flare up, which he finds ­dficult to deal with. “When I have to walk like a robot or lose my voice, my world feels ­intrinsically smaller,” Alex says.  “It really affects my confidence to be a part of society ­because I don’t want the world to see my symptoms. “I know others with Parkinson’s feel this way, too.” It is this feeling that drives Alex to continue with his epic fundraising ­adventures around the globe. He says: “Being physically restricted at times has taught me to be resilient. “That doesn’t stop me feeling angry but I use that anger and hatred for Parkinson’s to do ­positive things, such as raising money for research. “This ­disease can zap your self-worth but you can keep doing what you want to do, evenit means finding an ­alternative way of doing it. “I have hope in better treatments for Parkinson’s being discovered.

Mark Adams, chief executive of Community Integrated Care, believes thousands would have been saved – and has slammed plans for weekly tests in England as “too little, too late”. To date, Office for National Statistics figures show , care home ­residents have died with Covid-. And Mr Adams’ claim suggests some , could still be alivea robust testing regime had limited outbreaks. Accusing the Government of abandoned residents, he said: “If the priority had been, ‘Let’s just test everybody that’s coming into contact with vulnerable people’, you probably would have more than halved the number you lost in a care home, and maybe even made it a fraction of what it has been. “The Government clearly started off thinking, ‘We’re all going to get this, there are going to be about , people who die’. They’re mainly going to be old people who potentially might have died anyway and they might even save the NHS and local authorities moneythey pop their clogs early’.” Mr Adams spoke after regular testing was finally announced for care home staff in England. He said without twice-weekly testing, care homes and supported living homes would be left completely unprepared for a second, third or fourth wave of the virus. He stressed that twice-weekly testing is needed to stop infected staff bringing Covid- into homes – with residents tested by local public health nurses rather than carers. Mr Adams said: “Dealing with ­vulnerable and confused people who might have dementia, that’s a horrendous experience for them to go through. You really need to have experienced nurses doing the testing now.   “Our organisation has  nurses across  locations. But a great many social care environments are run where you don’t have nursing staff – you have highly trained care workers.“The test has a % failure rate just on the science. But thenyou add the human error into that there’s a risk. The ideal scenario is public health teams would have a dedicated team who visit care homes.” Mr Adams warned the toll could rise much higherthe Government fails to also boost testing in supported living environments. He said: “We talk about the , in nursing and care homes. There’s , in supported living. “The fact that they’re in a dferent building doesn’t mean the complexity of their condition has changed. Every time the Government pats itself on the back about gradually getting its act together five months too late, they’re talking about care homes and nursing homes – they’re not talking about this army of people who are waiting to have support themselves.” Charities have also demanded beefed-up testing for agency staff. The ONS found infection rates were higher in homes that used agency staff who worked across several sites. Professor Martin Green, chief executive of Care England, added: “Regular and routine testing is criticalwe are to garner a better understanding and keep at bay this virus. This initiative needs to be rolled out to all care homes, including adults with learning disabilities and also supported living.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn times of crisis, stocking up on essentials is normal human behaviour. But for around . ­million Brits, hoarding items is a serious issue, linked to anxiety and obsessive-compulsive disorders. And for many sufferers, the lockdown has exacerbated the problem because staying at home means there is nowhere to hide from the clutter. Jo Cooke, founder of Hoarding Disorders UK, says that since March, the organisation’s helpline has seen a spike in calls. But what exactly is hoarding and what can be done to stop it   Hoarding – once dismissed as an extension of other mental health conditions – was officially recognised as a disorder in its own right by the World Health Organization in . The NHS describes it as ­someone acquiring an ­excessive number of items and storing them in a chaotic manner, resulting in huge amounts of clutter. These hoards often interfere with daily le and the use of the home, such as making the shower or kitchen inaccessible. They also cause distress to the sufferer and their family. Hoarded homes also pose a number of safety issues, ­particularlythere is a fire. The severity is measured by a visual guide known as the Clutter Image Rating. Who is affected   Around two to five per cent of Brits are thought to be hoarders to some degree, but the true number could be higher because sufferers are often too ashamed to talk about it. Jo says: “This is an ­anxiety disorder, not people who are lazy or dirty. “They have emotional ­attachments to things, often ­triggered by bereavement or trauma, such as redundancy or empty nest syndrome.” Seek some support Reaching out for help is a vital first step when it comes to ­treating the condition. There are currently around  support groups in the UK – and self-diagnosed hoarder Lynn Howells runs one in Berkshire, with the support of Jo. It was set up by Silva Homes, the housing association -year-old Lynn works for. And the group’s monthly meetings, which are now taking place online, provide emotional support as well as practical tips to curb hoarding behaviours and cope with family tensions. Lynn says: “I’ve bought or kept things ‘just in case’ my whole adult le, and I’ve traced it back to the upset of being sent to boarding school. “Volunteering to run the ­support group has helped me a lot. Everyone’s story is unique but it is a relief to realise you are not alone.” How to tackle a hoardIf you feel able to declutter, Jo recommends starting small.She says: “Begin in the least emotional area, such as the ­hallway. Build five minutes into your daily routine to start and focus on the benefits of ­creating a more al home.” Lynn says that setting rules helped her feel comfortable enough to let possessions go. She explains: “For a hoarder, items have a perceived value, whether monetary or emotional. You also worry about where they will end up.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDozens of iconic buildings across Britain are being lit up blue this weekend as part of celebrations to mark the nd anniversary of the founding of the NHS. This weekend is marking the biggest thank-you yet not only to the NHS and key workers, but also to all those in the community whose support has helped us get through the pandemic. The events will reach a climax with a nation-wide clap at pm on Sunday when people are being asked to come out again on their doorsteps or stop what they’re doingto applaud and then spend some time with neighbours and friends to reflect on those connections that continue to strengthen our communities as we move into the next stage of the crisis. Brits have put a candle or a light in their window to remember all those we have lost to Covid-. At pm the Dean of St Pauls lit a candle on the West End portico of the cathedral in London. Landmarks all across the country have been lit in NHS blue, supported by the #LightItBlue campaign. Number  Downing Street is lit up and a candle is placed on the doorstep to remember the hundreds of key workers who have list their lives during the pandemic.Windsor Castle, where The Queen is currently staying, is also lit in blue this evening.  Kenilworth Castle is another building paying tribute to the NHS. They tweeted: Tonight, weaposre supporting the NHS and Togetheraposs Moment of Remembrance. We remember those we have lost and pay tribute to NHS staff, key workers and everyone who has played their part during the pandemic. #lightitblue#thankyoutogether.  The famous clock at Londonaposs Waterloo station is also lit up in blue, the colour of the NHS. Lordaposs Cricket Ground tweeted: Weaposre lighting the Pavilion blue tonight.On the weekend of @NHSEngland aposs birthday, weaposre joining with other landmarks from across the UK to #LightItBlue as we remember those we have sadly lost during the pandemic.The Eden Project in Cornwall, the windmill in Lytham St Annes in Lancashire, the arch at Wembley Stadium and The Royal Albert Hall are some other iconic venues to also light up blue tonight. And across the country, members of the public have lit candles and placed them in their windows in paying tribute to our heroes. One person tweeted: #NeverForgotten#LightItBlue for those we have loved and lost due to COVID . Another said: Remembering those we have sadly lost during the pandemic. Shining a light in my window #LightItBlue#ThankYouTogether. Thinking about all those who are no longer with us... Light a candle #LightItBlue#NHS#NHSBirthday, another said.  The Covid- outbreak has been the greatest challenge the NHS has faced since it was founded on  July . Premier League stars and match officials applauded healthcare professionals and other key workers before games kicked-off on Saturday afternoon. At pm on Sunday, broadcasters will suspend normal transmissions to encourage everybody to stop what they’re doing and join with othersin their streets or neighbourhoods to applaud not just the NHS and other key workers but all those who have volunteered or helped keep services and community networks going. Sir Simon Stevens, NHS Chief Executive, said: This year has been the most challenging in NHS history, with staff displaying extraordinary dedication, skill and compassion to care for the , patients with COVID- who needed specialist hospital treatment and many others besides. During this testing time our nurses, doctors, physios, pharmacists and countless more colleagues were sustained by the support of the public, not least through the weekly applause for key workers. No health service, not even the NHS, could have coped alone with this coronavirus pandemic. From bus drivers and teachers to care staff and food retailers and, of course, the public who took action to stay at home to stop infection spreading, everyone played their part. The NHS’s birthday this year not only offers the opportunity for us to say thank you to the nation, but for us all to come together at pm to pause and recognise all the work which has taken place in the last months and say a heartfelt thank you. The clap for carers at pm on a Thursday night became an established ritual during the Covid- plague – and a focal point for unity among neighbours, streets and whole towns. The idea for this weekendaposs tribute came from the newly founded Together coalition, which includes the CBI, trades unions, the Scouts and Guides. Justin Welby, Archbishop of Canterbury, said: “ My sincere hope is this weekend will serve as a powerful moment of remembrance, thanks and connection, as we come together and commit to helping to create kinder, closer more connected communities.” Others supporters include UK Sport, Clap for Carers founder Annemarie Plas and Baroness Doreen Lawrence. Ruth May, chief nursing officer for England, said: “Throughout its history the NHS has brought the whole country together, treating everyone based on need not ability to pay. So we’re honoured the Together coalition have chosen the NHS birthday to pull the country together.” Kwame Kwei-Armah, director of the Young Vic, said: “At a time when there is so much emphasis on what ides us, giving thanks and connecting with our communities is one of the things that unites us.” The last official Clap for Carers event was held on May .

Hand sanitiser was passed out to the guests and the coupleaposs witnesses had to sign the register, at St Georgeaposs Church in Leeds, with separate pens. But Heather and Tom finally wed, nearly four months after they had first intended to marry. Their original plans - a lavish ceremony in front of more than  guests at Greyfriars Kirk in Edinburgh - had to be axed because they were scheduled days into the lockdown back in March. Speaking from their home in Leeds, the devout Christians said: It wasnapost what we had planned but it was completely unique and really special. I know everyoneaposs wedding day is memorable but this one feels particularly memorable. Indeed, photos show some of the  or so guests wearing face masks in the church. Each seat in the building had a name label on the back to avoid people sitting down where others had sat.  Tape was put on the floor to help guests adhere to social distancing measures too. story: NewsMeghan Markle worryingly silent and struggling to cope with new LA le - relativeEXCLUSIVE: Duchess of Sussexs relative says she is has been unusually quiet with the toll of leaving the Royal family, falling out with pal Jessica Mulroney and an ongoing court case taking tollShareByHalina Watts:,  JUL NewsMeghan Markle and Prince Harry have had a dficult year, with family and legal issues ", url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMeghan and Prince Harry must be “struggling” to cope as their royal rt is played out in a legal battle, a relative has claimed. In documents lodged at the High Court this week, the Duchess of Sussex has insisted she was left “unprotected” by the Royal Family while pregnant with son Archie. It’s the latest salvo fired in her continuing fight with a newspaper over published extracts of a letter she sent to dad Thomas. And the stress of their new le is also said to be taking its toll on Harry who is missing the close bond he once had with his brother Prince William. The relative of Meghan, who does not want to be named, told the Sunday Mirror: “She has gone very quiet. I think she is likely to be feeling extremely low and probably struggling.  “The legal battle and the increased tension it’s created with the royals due to the information that’s coming out has to be putting a lot of strain on them both. “Meghan’s been a lot more distant and introverted over the last few weeks – her family is worried. And Harry must be tormented by his fractured family ties. He was particularly down on William’s birthday on June .” This week it emerged -year-old Meghan has named in court papers five friends who gave an interview to US People magazine defending her and criticising her father.But she denies authorising them to do it.  She insisted her friends spoke to the magazine only because they were worried for her. Meghan also claimed she had been the subject of numerous damaging and distressing articles, with Kensington Palace ordering her to say nothing but “no comment”. Her legal document stated: “As her friends had never seen her in this state before, they were rightly concerned for her welfare, specically as she was pregnant, unprotected by the Institution, and prohibited from defending herself.” The couple quit as frontline royals in January to move to Canada before settling in Los Angeles. Meghan is suing the Mail on Sunday for publishing extracts from the handwritten letter she sent to her father Thomas, , in August . It was written three months after he was unable to walk her down the aisle following a heart attack. The former Suits actress claims the letter was private.  The newspaper says Mr Markle wanted its content published to correct any  impression her friends had given about what it contained when they gave their magazine interviews. Meghan has identied one of her five pals, Friend A, as the person who told People magazine the letter said: “Dad, I’m so heartbroken. I love you. I have one father. “Please stop victimising me through the media so we can repair our relationship.”  In court documents Meghan claimed this was an “unfortunately inaccurate” portrayal of her letter, insisting many times she had known nothing of her closest friends’ decision to go public. Her friends now face the prospect of having to testy on oath in the High Court that this is true. Meghan is also believed to have been hit hard by her spat with long-time pal Jessica Mulroney who was caught up in a race row last month.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA new lockdown map for Leicester has been produced after residents were left confused.The East Midlands city was placed into a local lockdown last month, the first place to do so, following a worrying rise in the number of coronavirus cases.Dferent versions of the map showed boundaries in the area that has tighter restrictions. They caused confusion among locals as to whether or not they fell into the boundary. Now Leicester City Police have tweeted a further version of the map which covers the same lockdown area but has all the affected zone shaded in pink.Are you affected by the Leicester lockdown  Email  webnews@mirrorThe police say the latest version is more viewer-friendly, LeicestershireLive reports.The force is currently running Operation Integrate where it is policing two parts of the county with separate legal status. Within the lockdown zone, that covers the whole city and some outlying areas pubs, restaurants, hairdressers and cinemas are not yet allowed to re-open and non-essential shops had to close again. Outside the zone all those businesses can stay open or re-open from today.  The Leicester Lockdown has been put in place to try to stop infection after a recent spike of Coronavirus cases in the city. Last week, residents in villages were left baffled as one side of the street was inside the boundary, but the other was not. In Scraptoft, Kathleen McDonagh, , will have to wait at least two weeks before she can go to the pub or the hair salon.  In contrast, Veronica Cayless, also , who lives opposite her, is free to head to her local now as she is outside of the lockdown boundary. Itaposs a similar situation in Thurncourt, another area in Leicester. Residents in the lockdown boundary are separated by just a wooden picket fence. It has caused confusion for Helen Bale, , who lives inside the lockdown zone, but works outside of it.  My boss called me and said how does it fall for you  If I donapost go in, I donapost get paid. I just donapost see how it is going to work, she told Mail Online. Neighbour Lisa Jones, , was also left confused by the measures as she too lives in the lockdown area but isnapost sureshe can cross the other side of the fence to go to the essential shops. Images of deserted streets in Leicester show the stark reality of a city forced into local lockdown.  Photographs taken last week show city centre streets, previously bustling, now almost completely empty.

story: NewsSAS TV hero brands government disgrace over failure to combat medics suicideEXCLUSIVE: Mark Billy Billingham, star of SAS Who Dares Wins, spoke out following death of special forces medic Staff Sgt Jamie Ferguson, , who shot himself on Army base last month.ShareCommentsBySean Rayment:,  JUL NewsSpecial forces medic Staff Sgt Jamie Ferguson, , who shot himself on an Army base last month", url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA telly SAS hero has branded the Government’s failure to combat veterans’ suicide “a disgrace”. Mark “Billy” Billingham, a star of SAS Who Dares Wins, spoke out following the death of special forces medic Staff Sgt Jamie Ferguson, , who shot himself on an Army base last month. The Sunday People revealed he made a video saying: “I asked for help but no one was ­listening. They didn’t understand.” His widow Sammi, , who had a son with Jamie, and two daughters from another marriage, wants the Government to admit there is a problem with suicide in veterans’ and hold a full and open investigation into her husband’s death. Billy, , said: “It’s an absolute tragedy. You are not going to ­prevent all deaths but surely the MoD and the Army can do far more. It’s clear the MoD doesn’t care – once you’re out of the door it’s clear you are not its problem and that’s wrong. “The MoD doesn’t know how many veterans are killing themselves and that’s disgraceful – that ­disgusts me.” Staff Sgt Ferguson, originally from Leicestershire, joined up at  and was in the Royal Army Medical Corps. Among the hundreds of lives he saved with the SAS in Iraq and Afghanistan were victims of a  checkpoint ambush by a rogue Afghan cop in Helmand.  He was treated for post-traumatic stress last year after failing to save a soldier trampled by an ­elephant in an anti-poaching ­operation in Malawi. MPs last week told the Sunday People his ­suicide, at Leuchars Military Base, Fe, should be a “catalyst for change” for the way that the MoD treats soldiers with mental health problems. Billy, who spent  years with the Paras and the SAS, said: “With over  veteran suicides since  that’s a dficult number to get your head around. “Why are they not getting help with PTSD or other mental health problems ” Billy, who has guarded A-list stars such as Tom Cruise, Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie, has been ­decorated for bravery and had people die in his arms.He said he thought people with PTSD were weak until an SAS friend developed it. “I realised he had PTSD and it was something very real and very dangerous,” he recalled. Billy praised the Sunday People’s Save Our Soldiers campaign,which calls for an overhaul of how the MoD tackles PTSD and other mental health issues. He said there should be a ­specic centre giving veterans and ­members of the armed forces world class treatment rather than a ­“confusing” multi-agency approach.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailStreets in Soho, central London, were packed last night with drinkers desperate to enjoy their first pints in bars in more than  days due to lockdown. Clips posted online show joyful people celebrating and engaging closely with those around them. However the Government had advised Brits continue to keep one metre apart from others despite allowing bars and restaurants to reopen on Saturday July . One man, who passed through the busy roads, told : Walking down old Compton Street felt like wading through a Petri dish.  And that was at about :pm. Not much chance to socially distance even just walking down the street. Another video shared online shows a man twerking against a car trying to navigate through the crowds. The twerker is moved on but the car struggles to get through Soho as other drinkers move into the road. In each video, police officers are seen but signicantly outnumbered by the drinkers. But police had warned Saturday night would be as busy as New Yearaposs Eve for forces across England. Nevertheless, the ugly scenes sparked a furious backlash on social media.  One shocked woman wrote on Twitter : Just seen scenesSoho pubs... my heart goes out to those health care workers and their families who died of Covid to save the rest of us... disgusting lack of respect. And one man shared video of groups gathered in the streets, writing: Soho lockdown is over. Another fumed: Just seen the scenes in Soho. Itaposs asthe health care workers who risked their lives trying to deal with the pandemic were just wasting their time. And Borough Market, also in the capital, was heaving with drinkers pictured sipping foamy pints. They too were bunched together on the street.  Experts predicted pub-goers would sink a staggering  million pints at , establishments across England on Saturday alone. Some opened their doors at am to accommodate the demand. But prices for beer, wine, cider and spirits were hiked as pubs, including Wetherspoons, desperately tried to make up for lost business. Nevertheless, people were queuing to get in some pubs across England. There was a wait of around an hour just to get inside The Regal, a Wetherspoon in Cambridge.  Meanwhile AE departments prepared for a surge in booze-fuelled patients by setting up tents outside hospitals to keep people socially distanced as they waited. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Wildle charities have expressed concern at the unexplained deaths of more than  elephants across Botswana. The creatures have suddenly collapsed into heaps on the ground since the start of May in the Okavango Panhandle region.The government is yet to explain what has happened to the animals but has ruled out poaching, as all the carcasses have remained intact. But National Park Rescue is concerned at what it believes is slow progress. Mark Hiley, co-founder of National Park Rescue, said today: Elephants began dying in huge numbers in early May and the government would normally respond within days to an event of this scale. Yet here we are, months later, with no testing completed and with no more information than we had at the start.Mass elephant deaths on this scale are almost unprecedented, certainly in Botswana. A potential correlation between these and the coronavirus pandemic is yet to be ruled out.Youaposre not going to be able to get the elephants to do social-distancing, and youaposre not going to be able to inoculate them, Chris Thouless, head of research at Save the Elephants, said.  But the professional doesnapost believe authorities are dragging their feet. He continued: This is pretty remote country, hearing about the carcasses, getting in there, taking a whole range of samples, knowing how and where to get them from, ... that is a pretty dficult task. Mmadi Reuben, principal veterinary officer in the Department of Wildle and National Parks, said: A government investigating team has been on the ground since the first cases were reported. Botswana responded swtly.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTravel firms have slammed the governmentaposs new Covid- holiday traffic light system as sunseekers are warned their flights could be cancelled on short notice. Some countries given the green light from July  still have their borders closed to British tourists, and holiday firms claim utter confusion is putting people off from booking a trip.Only  of the  approved destinations are open to British arrivals without any restrictions, with some countries forcing travellers to undergo health screening at airports or provide up-to-date test results proving they donapost have coronavirus. Confusion over air corridors and restrictions means airlines are planning their schedules hand to mouth and holidaymakers should brace for flights to be cancelled or changed. Travel industry leaders hit out at the government for publishing contradictory advice for holidaymakers - the Department for Transportaposslist of approved destinations conflicts with guidance from the Foreign and Commonwealth Office . They have called for a single list of countries where there are no restrictions for Britons.Noel Josephides, the chairman of Sunvil, told the Sunday Times: It is highly confusing for travellers. We have two dferent sets of advice it is very odd. Itaposs as though government departments donapost actually speak to each other. All we want is one list.Travel consultant Paul Charles, from the Quash Quarantine campaign, claims Britons were being put off from booking trips abroad. He said: There is utter confusion: the two lists do not tally and consumers are going to be extremely confused. Currently, people have to check both lists, the government website for entry requirements and also contact the country they want to visit to make sure the information is up to date. The DfT published its travel corridor list of  destinations, plus  British Overseas Territories, on Friday. English travellers can visit without having to quarantine for  days upon their . Australia and Canada, for example, are on the DfTaposs list but both remain closed to British arrivals.  The Cayman Islandsapos borders are still closed to people who are not citizens or legal residents. People who arenapost citizens will have to quarantine at a government facility for  days at their own expense. Direct flights to Greece are banned until July . Visitors to Austria will have to provide a negative Covid- test that is less than four days old. In the Bahamas, the test result must be less than  days old and passengers must undergo a temperature check.  In addition to restrictions, British travellers also have to worry about their flights being cancelled or changed.Airlines expert John Strickland, director of JLS Consulting, told the Mail on Sunday: A number of airlines are planning their schedules on a very short term, hand to mouth basis.Several airlines have planned flights and put them on sale, only to find that Government policies and regulatory conditions in one country or another have meant that it is not possible to operate and have then had to cancel them and go back to square one. I don’t believe airlines are deliberately or maliciously cancelling flights. The colour-coded traffic light system decides which countries are considered safe to travel to.  Green is given to approved countries, amber is for countries considered less safe, and red means passengers ing from those countries will need to self-isolate for  days. The DfT published a list of  countries and territories where English tourists can visit without self-isolating on their . It features popular short-haul destinations such as Spain, France, Italy, Turkey, Greece and Cyprus, as well as long-haul locations including Australia, Barbados, Hong Kong, Japan, New Zealand and Vietnam. China, Portugal, Thailand, the Males and the US are among the notable absentees. The FCO published a separate list of  countries and territories which will be exempt from its advisory against all non-essential travel from Saturday, making it easier for UK tourists to be covered by travel insurance while visiting.
